person.note: The interchange of the initial א and י may perhaps reflect another dialect. In vol 1, under Miriam (45), p. 243 and n. 96, p. 247, I note the case of the title אמא transcribed as ימה. This may be associated with the phenomenon of the fall of the initial א in some dialects, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29.

See above, n. 3. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. Note, however, the parallel to Babylonian Amoraic names in this bowl.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: All these versions are recorded on the bowl. The name intended is אחתא דאבה, i.e. in Aramaic sister of the father, see above, n. 1. The form ʾḤDB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 25). The name probably means “father’s sister.” On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. So on p. 27. In this version the fall of the ח and one additional א are probably scribal errors, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2.
So on pp. 30-1. These last two versions indicate clearly that this is the intended name. The additional ו in the second version probably reflects the spoken dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
See above, n. 4. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: Both forms are found on the bowl. On the interchange of ו and י as possible scribal errors, see Introduction 2.7.1. On the reversal of ב and ת also as possible scribal errors see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20. The final דו in the second version is inexplicable.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
See above, n. 4. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

So in the Florence II-I-9 and Jerusalem – Yad Harav Herzog 1 Mss. In others the reading is אייבו. On the single י see Introduction 2.3.4.3.
On the gender of this person see Rosenthal, Rabbi Hiyya,” 309-12.
Appears in rabbinic literature as a relative of a prominent rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Aybo [2]), p. 418, but not included in the statistics.
This is a genealogy of a Babylonian family of sages.
On this date see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
The scribes of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

In Aramaic – בת כהן שזינתא הויא. אקפה רב חמא בר טוביה חבילי זמורות ושרפה (She was the daughter of a priest who fornicated. Rav Ḥama (13) bar Tobias (12) covered her with bundles of branches and burnt her).
Appears in rabbinic literature in that rabbis execute her according to Jewish law, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Rav Joseph (3), who died in 323 CE, according to ShGa § 173, comments on his faulty action, see Introduction 8.2.1.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, the parallel between this name and אמא שלום of rabbinic literature (see vol. 1, Salome [7] B/F, p. 249) suggests that this client was Jewish.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, the presence of an אמא שלום (see previous) on this bowl suggests that this client was Jewish, see above, n. 2. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.

Jewishness suggested based on family member’s name (Simon [40]), but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. The human statue on which the inscription appears also militates against Jewishness, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The epitaph is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.

The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as the name Ḥananiah (32) may suggest, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, memebres of this family are presented in human form on their sarcophagi, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Buried in the Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beth Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.
In the Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. This is the suggested reading of the editor, see Introduction 2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.7.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.

state.note: Incantation bowls, Moussyaieff collection; Shøyen collection

One person in this one, however, is designated by the title רב (Rav), see Introduction 6.6.1. The incantation bowl also mentions Joshua ben Perahiah, see Introduction 6.7.1.

She is the wife of Rav Huna (1), who died in 297 CE, according to ShGa § 167, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.

In a Palestinian or European context the two names mentioned in this inscription (Naʿomi [2] and Ḥananiah) inscribed in Semitic characters would insure their Jewishness. However, Palmyra in this context is unique, see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.

So in the Vatican 111 Ms. On the interchange of י and ו as scribal praxis see Introduction 2.7.1.
So in the Venice (1520) print. On the replacement of letters (in this case ר and י) as a scribal error see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20.
She is the wife of a rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2.

On the problem of understanding her name as a proper name, and for a suggestion that it is a nickname, see S. Naeh, “Freedom and Celibacy: A Talmudic Variation on Tales of Temptation and Fall in Genesis and its Syrian Background,” in Judith Frishman and L. van Rompay (eds.) The Book of Genesis in Jewish and Oriental Christian Interpretation (Louvain 1997) 73-89.
Her husband was a student of Rav (Abba [70]), who died in 247 CE, according to ShGa § 160, see Introduction 8.2.1.
The letter א is a vocalization, see Introduction 2.3.5.3. The וי suffix is probably the result of Iranian influence, see Introduction 2.4.1.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

Described as having helped Bakru, a nobleman of Edessa (ܒܟܪܘ ܐܒܝܐ ܕܐܘܪܗܝ).
Described in the text as ܥܒܪܝܬܐ (Hebrew).

Because she is described as being worshiped by the people of Edessa, scholars have attempted to explain her as a metaphor, e.g. for the Jewish Mezuzah (a written document – from כתב which protects, see C. Clermont-Ganneau, “La Lettre de Jésus au roi Abgar, la Koutbi juive adorée à Edesse et la mezoûzah,” in Recueil d’archéologie orientale 3 [Paris, 1900], 216-23). This is of course speculation, but it raises doubts about the historicity of this person.
Mentioned in a ms dated to the 5th century CE.

So in the St. Petersburg – RNL Evr. I 187 Ms, see previous note. In the Vilna print we find מעורת. The name was obviously not stable, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. The interchange of ו and ג is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20.
So in the Vatican 140 Ms. On the interchange of ר and ד see Introduction 2.7.1.
In the text she is described as driving her slave to his death.
Appears in rabbinic literature as a legal precedent, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Appears in amoraic sources, see Introduction 8.2.6.
Her son appears in rabbinic literature and bears the title רב (Rav), see Introduction 6.6.2.
Her grandson was a student of Rav (Abba [70]), who died in 247 CE, according to ShGa § 160, see Introduction 8.2.1.
Appears in rabbinic literature, and the rabbis bring her action as an example of sanctioned Jewish healing practices, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Her son was a studentof Rav Judah (3), who died in 299 CE, according to ShGa § 168, see Introduction 8.2.1.
On the gender of this person see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 35-6.
Appears in rabbinic literature as a relative of a prominent rabbi (bSan 5a), see Introduction 6.6.2. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Martha [3]), p. 423, but not included in the statistics.
This is a genealogy of a Babylonian family of sages.
On this date see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
In Palmyran script, see Introduction 2.8.2. In the initial publication, this name was read [מר]תא, but Misgav, Ossuaries, 46, claims that the ר can be read, see Introduction 2.1
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Martha [4]), p. 423, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On the interchange of א and י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Greek. On the transliteration of Semitic names into Greek see Introduction 2.2.2.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.5.2. The inscription is found on a base of a (cult) statue, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
In Palmyrene script, see above, n. 14. The inscription is bilingual. So in the Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On the interchange of א and י suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.4.

The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as the name Ḥananiah (31) suggests, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, they are presented in human form on their sarcophagi, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

In Nabatean script, see Introduction 2.8.3. The reading is according to Hirschberg, EI 12 (1975) 146. The editors read מונה. On the interchange of א and ה as suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25.
In Aramaic – ברת שנין תלתין ותמני.
Jewishness indicated by the name Samuel (48) mentioned in the inscription, see Introduction 6.5.4.1.
The epitaph is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
The letter interchange may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20.

So in the Vatican 130 Ms. This name was obviously not stable and unknown to the scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. It is impossible to speculate on the original name. On the double ו see Introduction 2.3.4.3. On the interchange of the ה with the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25.
So in the Vatican 140 Ms, and see previous note. The יו may be a scribal error, to replace the double ו. On the interchange of the ה with the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25.
Appears in rabbinic literature as a name of a woman in a Jewish divorce bill, see Introduction 6.6.3.

Buried in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.

On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.persName: ܩܡܨܘDsFounder of a Sabbatean sect in Edessa
person.note: In one of Ephrem’s Hymns against the Heresies a woman is described with the words: ܐܝܬܬܐ ܠܫܒܵܬܝܐ (Sabbatean woman). In a letter of Jacob of Edessa, he explains who she was “There was in Edessa a woman … She was called by her parents Qamsou” (ܐܝܬܝܗ݀ܿ ܗܘܬ ܗܟܝܠ ܗܕܐ ܐܢܬܬܐ ܐܢܫ ܒܐܘܪܗܝ ... ܡܬܩܪܝܐ ܗܘܬ ܕܝܢ ܒܝܬ ܐܒܵܗܝܗܿ ܩܡܨܘ, see Wright, Ibid., p. 25) who dressed as a man and was ordained and then founded the Sabbatean sect in Edessa.
The sect she founded was a mixture of Jewish and Christian elements. Perhaps she derived the Jewish elements from a Jewish background, though this is not decisive.
This is the date in which the text where she is mentioned is first cited.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2, and contains biblical names, see Introduction 6.5.
The epitaph is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3
On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26. On the loss of the י see Introduction 2.3.5.6.
The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.

So in Cambridge - T-S F1 (1) 1 Ms. The different suffix is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20.

So is the text quoted by several of the rishonim, see A. Liss, The Babylonian Talmud, Tractate Yebamoth (II) (Institute for the Complete Israeli Talmud; Jerusalem 1986) 395, in the apparatus criticus (Hebrew). On the additional י in the suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.3.
Appears in rabbinic literature as the daughter of a prominenet rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2.
Her father was a contemporary of Rav Ḥisda (Ḥesediah [1]), who died in 309 CE, according to ShGa § 168, see Introduction 8.2.1.
On the additional י see Introduction 2.3.5.2.
Appears in rabbinic literature as a member of a prominent family, see Introduction 6.6.2. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Shilat [1]), p. 426, but not included in the statistics.
This is a genealogy of a Babylonian family of sages.
On this date see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.

The tomb is pagan, but this part may have been sold to a Jew, as the name Ḥananiah suggests, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, this family is presented in human form on their sarcophagi, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
In Palmyran script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Shelamzion [3]), p. 426, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.
Jewishness suggested based on grandfather’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Also, the human statue on which the inscription was found makes its Jewishness unlikely, see Introduction 6.8.1.
The epitaph is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

div.note: The forms ʾBN and ʾBNH are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 16).

אחת/ אחתאmeans “sister” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 42). The name אחתו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 69). The form ʾḤT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 24) and for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 4). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
Transliteration according to Isbell. MSF no. 27 gives Ahata.
The form ʾḤDB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 25). The name probably means “father’s sister.” On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
Gordon, Orientalia 10 (1941) 349, gives the transliteration Ahatabi.
The name probably means “father’s sister.” On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
In the Bible אבי is feminine (2 Kgs 18:2). איבו is the name of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 44). This is the correct reading of this name (Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 309-12, n. 60).
אמטבי means the mother of Tabi (see under Ṭobiah (8) [B/M]). It is not recorded elsewhere.
אימרנא means “rebellion” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 51). The form ʾMRT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 75).
אמא/אימא means “mother” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 50). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. This name is recorded in Palmyra (ʾMʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 68-9).
Palmyrene name (ʾMBY, see Stark, PNPI, 5).
Palmyrene name (ʾQMT, see Stark, PNPI, 7).
The names means “daughter of luck.”
The form BTḤW is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 13). The name means “daughter of month” or “new daughter.”
My transliteration. Isbell offered none.
The form BT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 91). The form BTY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 13).
Transliteration according to AMB.
The form BTMLKW is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 13). The name means “king’s daughter.”
The form BTʿN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 92). The form BTʿʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 13).
The name means “daughter of Sabbath” or “seventh daughter,” like the Hebrew בת שבע.
My transliteration. Levene, CMB, M108, gives the transliteration “Bat-Šabbea”.
The name means “sixth daughter.”
Palmyrene name (BTŠMYʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 13). The name means “daughter of heaven.”
דונג means “wax” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 286). The form DNJY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 244).
זבינתא means “goods, bargain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 379). The form ZBNT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 294).
Transliteration according to CAMIBBM.
זויתא means “joint, angle, corner” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 386). The form ZWT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 303).
זוני means “belt, armour” in Aramaic (from Greek ζώνη, Jastrow, DTTBYML, 236). The form ZNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 302).
זיו/זיוא means “splendour, glory” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 392). The וי suffix is probably the result of Iranian influence, see Introduction 2.4.1.
זכות means “acquittal, favorable judgment” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 398.
Palmyrene name ḤBʾ(Stark, PNPI, 19).
The forms ḤBL/ḤBLT/ḤBLH are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 174). The form ḤBWLʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 19).

חרותא means “dried up twig” or “blackness, black sediment” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 500). The form ḤRWT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 186). The form ḤRTʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 23).
חתה/חתי means “to dig, to take out coals” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 512s). The form ḤTY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 176) and for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 24).
This is AMB’s transliteration. Levene gives „Hatoi“.
The form ṬLY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 389).
The form YLṬ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 682).
The form YNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 686).
Transliteration according to Isbell.
Name not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6. The name means “the one from Jerusalem.”
The form KTBY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 495).
כתמא means “bloodstain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 681). The form KTM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 495).
My transliteration. Schwab gives Khatima.
מחלף means “sharp knife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 762).
I follow Levene, CMB, 41, in this transliteration. AMB gives Mahlepa, Isbell gives Mahlapta.
This name seems to be a combination of מלכא (=king, see under Malkiah [B/M]) and מן (=of), meaning something like “of the king”
The form MʿR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 554).
מרתא means “mistress” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). The name is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 695); and in Palmyra (MRTʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 97).
This is the feminine form of the name משרשיא recorded for males both in rabbinic literature and in the incantations bowls, see under M/S-H. On the suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.6.
So in Geller, OLP 17 (1986) 114. CAMIBBM 024A refers to him as “Mešaretana”.
נוכרייא/נוכרי/נוכראה/נוכרא means “strange, stranger, gentile” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 887). The form NKR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 598).
נפיא means “fan, winnow, sieve” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 923).
עמרניתא means “wooly, tufty substance” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1091). עמרת is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 919). ʿMRT is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 106).
ʾT is a typical Palmyrene prefix for female names, see Stark, PNPI, 46-7. This name, is, however, not recorded.
Palmyrene name (Stark, PNPI, 47 records only this example).
צפרתא in Aramaic means “small bird,” (Jastrow, DTTBYML,1299).
צפרא means “morning” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1298). The form ṢFRH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 373). The form ṢPRʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
קיטי means “a curtain or sheet consisting of patches pieced together” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 386). The form QṬN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 484).
קמצא means “locust” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML,). QMṢ is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 488). On the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1, p. 28.
The form RʾY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 263). On the theophoric suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.5.

שושנה in the Bible is the lily (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4). The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1118, and שושנת no. 1119). Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Iranian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel (C.A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions [The Anchor Bible; New York 1977] 77-116).

On this name as being female see Rosenthal, Rabbi Hiyya, 308-9, n. 58 and see also Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 285-6. For the Nabatean שילת see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1124. The form ŠLWT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 356).
My suggestion. CAMIBBM 024A gives the transliteration Shiltay.
Palmyrene name (ŠLʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 51).
The name שלמציון (=“the peace of Zion,” or “the wholeness of Zion”) was not biblical. It was a new and popular name for women in the Second Temple period in Palestine. It went out of use soon after.

תם means “perfect, unblemished” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1674. The form TM is a recorded name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 136). The form TM’ is recorded for women in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 56).
